prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for buying pregnant wife yoga pass for her birthday
My wife is 16 weeks pregnant.  She has a something called hypermesis which is "morning sickness" all the time, even waking up in the middle of the night to vomit.   I told her to ask her doctor for a medical leave so she is currently on temporary disability.  She stays in bed most of the day and only leaves the house to go to the hospital where she gets IV fluids for dehydration/vitamin deficiency.     
I know I always feel better when I exercise and it helps with depression.  I think she is getting depressed because she misses her job.  I think she should leave the house and get some fresh air and stretch, so I got her a yoga pass for her birthday.   I researched local studios and found one that had prenatal yoga.   When she got the email gift certificate while I was at work, she didn't call to say thank you.  When I got home, I asked her if she got the email and she just gave me a look.  I could tell she didn't like my present.  She says she is too sick to do yoga.   Ok, maybe.   She thinks it is a rude present and that I am "tone deaf."  I can get her another present...don't know what.   I don't think my present makes me a bad person, though.   She might feel better soon and want to take yoga classes.  She told her friends about it and they agreed with her that I am being an asshole.  I think it is rude to be so critical of my present.
"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's see. The user is asking whether the person who bought the yoga pass for their pregnant wife on her birthday is in the wrong. The wife has hypermesis, which is severe morning sickness. The husband thought she might benefit from yoga to combat possible depression from missing work and being cooped up. She didn't like the gift, said she was too sick, and her friends agreed she was right to be upset.

First, I need to consider the husband's intentions. He wanted to help her feel better by encouraging exercise and getting out of the house. That's a good intention. But he might not have considered how she's feeling physically. Hypermesis is really severe; she's on bed rest and IV fluids. Suggesting yoga might come off as insensitive because she's already struggling to leave the house for medical reasons. Maybe she's too unwell to handle any physical activity, and the gift felt dismissive of her condition. The husband didn't consult her about the gift before buying it, which could be a mistake. Even if the intention was good, not checking in with her about what she actually needs or wants might have been a misstep. The fact that she and her friends think he's being an asshole suggests that the gift was ill-received, possibly because it didn't acknowledge the reality of her health. So, even if he meant well, the action might have been tone-deaf. That would make the answer A, since the author is in the wrong for not considering her physical state and the appropriateness of the gift given her condition.
